comments.text:
+IceMetalPunk
I think you're confusing a few points.
1. The universe does have a center, which all the galaxies are moving away 
from. That's how we got to the big bang theorem - concluding that it all 
must have come from a single point. Physicists have even concluded the size 
of this single point (around the size of a pea).
I unsubscribed from minute physics because they aren't very good at 
explaining anything and they don't seem to understand stuff very well 
themselves. Try Sixty Symbols
and their other channels like numberphile. Real physicists working in the 
field.
2. We know how fast the universe is expanding - the speed of light. That's 
a finite change over time, so it's exactly like infinity+1.
comments.author: Plague Doctor

comments.text:
+Plague Doctor Well....yes and no. There are different sizes of infinity. 
First, there are the categories of countable and uncountable infinity. Then 
there are the measurements, called alephs. Aleph-null is the start, then 
you go to aleph-1, then aleph-2, etc. It's quite interesting, really; you 
should look it up sometime :)
That said, the universe doesn't fall into this, I don't think. However, 
when we talk about its expansion, we're just talking about the motion of 
any two points away from each other. It doesn't presuppose a size to the 
universe. There's a size to the portion of the universe we can observe, but 
there's more beyond that. Check out MinutePhysics' video on the Big Bang 
for a little perspective--it wasn't something that had a center or a 
location. It happened everywhere at once, and the expansion continues 
everywhere at once with no center. If we were even just one light-year away 
from Earth, our visible universe would now include more of the total 
universe than it does now, and there's no reason to suspect that would ever 
stop as we move farther in space. In other words, though we're not sure, 
our best guess is that the universe is, in fact, infinite. Infinite and 
growing; which does not make infinity plus 1, it just makes infinity still. 
Like adding the set of irrational numbers to the set of rational numbers.
comments.author: IceMetalPunk

comments.text:

No, size is an attribute of something finite, even if colloquially we say 
things like "infinitely large". Something that is "infinitely large" by 
definition doesn't have a quantifiable size, so it can't expand. We can 
quantify how fast the universe is expanding, therefore it isn't infinite.
TL;DR You can't have infinity + 1.

We mix drugs like alcohol and caffeine with other things for flavor and to 
lessen its affects (particularly alcohol). I wonder if the same can be done

comments.text:
Mixing alcohol or caffeine with something like juice or milk doesn't lessen 
it's effects, it just takes longer to drink the shot of vodka when it's

can say they don't physically cancel each other out, despite what it may 
feel like.
comments.author: TheBusyJane

comments.text:
That's actually a super important conversation going on right now. Because 
we're adding things like energy drinks to alcohol, people can get more and 
more intoxicated while skipping the whole 'I'm feeling sooo sleeeepy' 
stage. Which, in theory, could be partially responsible for the apparent 
rise in alcohol related violence.
comments.author: magicalmusicbox

comments.text:
I'm not so sure it truly lessens the effects when it comes to caffeine + 
alcohol. But yes, there are drugs that counter other drugs' effects. One 
class is known as agonists, which mimic neurotransmitters, and the other is 
known as antagonists, which block those same receptors. They do cancel each 
other out and are often used as treatments, especially when overdosing (for 
example, naloxone is an opiod antagonist, while many painkillers are opioid 
agonists. Naloxone is often a treatment for painkiller overdose, and a 
consumer injection pen for it was just approved by the FDA).

But the best way to reduce the effects of a drug is to not take too much of 
it, if any, if you don't need to.
comments.author: IceMetalPunk

top_comment.text:
Hallucinogens rarely cause true hallucinations. Most often they result in 
fractal shapes, breathing imagery, and washing body sensations. The biggest 
change is aural, which is a shift in consciousness that reduces the ability 
to perform linear thought (like reading or performing mathematics), and 
increases the ability to grasp emotional concepts, things that involve 
empathy and perceiving the interconnectedness of life.

The easiest way to explain it is that it's like the emotional and spiritual 
becomes vaguely physical. This can definitely cause discomfort and fear, if 
individuals are going through emotional stress that they have not 
addressed. That very change in perception can be immensely valuable in 
taking a step out of the hedge maze to work through complex personal 
trauma, and is currently being used with success is therapy.

(A true hallucination would be where one was unable to distinguish that 
which is real, from that which is not. It's possible to achieve this with 
high doses, but this is not recommended for obvious reasons.)﻿

oh my god, finally I can correct Hank on something that he overgeneralised.
Hallucinogens aren't 'also known as' psychedelics; hallucinogens are the 
class, and psychedelics are effectively a branch of drugs within that 
class. LSD is classified as a psychedelic and with this also considered a 
hallucinogen (although the term 'hallucinogen' is a slight case of false 
advertisement by definition), whereas a drug like Salvia Divinorum is a 
hallucinogen and sometimes called a dissociative, but isn't a psychedelic. ﻿

+Donnie I am in the same boat.  If left to my own devices then I typically

simply not enough.  But I have that jet-lagged feeling most of my life.  
Caffeine helps, but is not reliable if I use it every day.  Having a 
regular healthy diet and exercise helps a little bit, but still does not 
bring be back into sync with the world.

But every once in a while, maybe once every 5-8 weeks, there comes a few 
days in a row where my sleep cycle matches up with real life, and I get to 
feel normal for a bit.  Feels a lot like being superman for a few days; 
Plenty of motivation, plenty of energy, and life just works.  When it comes 
around then I get as much as I can done because I know it is always short 
lived.
comments.author: CaedenV

comments.text:
Large breakfast at noon as I wake up, large meal during the evening (6PM), 
then snacks during the night.

I've tried a lot of tricks to get me asleep earlier. Some did help:
1. Do some quick exercise that strains my whole body, but not as much as to 
break a sweat or have muscles hurt. Then I go to bed, and keep my muscles 
strained, and take deep frequent breaths. Then I relax muscles slowly 
during 1-2 minutes, reducing the frequency of the breaths. As I slowly 
relax, I can feel my heart lowering its rhythm, and a lot of the times, 
just after the full relaxation, with my last deep exhalation, I am able to 
fall asleep. Sex would be more efficient at this task, but I won't wake my 
wife in the middle of the night.
2. My friends advised me, and it works I think, to not do anything 1-2 
hours before sleep. In "anything" I mean work, learning, social media and 
stuff. Nothing that would take you in too much, and nothing that you'll 
want to finish. During those 1-2 hours maybe even get bored a bit, but just 
a bit. They also told me to do more cardio during the day, but for some 
reason I find it harder to fall asleep after the days where I've gone on 
long bicycle trips.

"I would be tired during working hours, but somehow wake up after dinner, 
and not be able to sleep until late again. " - 100% me. Noon is pretty 
normal for me, but by 2-3PM I can literally fall asleep standing. Immensely 
sleepy. By 5PM I get my productivity up again, then that darn large meal, 
and from 8PM until late night or early morning I can do very cool stuff. 
Naps helped with the immediate condition during afternoon, but later on I 
wouldn't get to my max. productivity. I used to try coffee, but it didn't 
help, and only made things worse. Like no effect for 1-2 hours, then 
restlessness, then a huge crash after which I'm only good for playing 
timekiller games.

It's weird though that when I went on vacation, and after a night and half 
day without sleep (landed at midnight, check in at midday), just the second 
day I got my sleep hours from 10PM to 6AM each day without a single 
problem. No trouble sleeping, no trouble waking up, cheerful during the 
day. So it has something to do with work. Maybe I get sleepy earlier, but 
this much information and brain stimulation as "Internet" keeps me awake. 
Being that my hotel had worse WiFi than the connection I used to have at 
home via Dial-up 14 years ago, I was basically offline. So no internet, and 
lots of stuff to do and places to see = good night sleep.
comments.author: Donnie

comments.text:
What are you meal times? Are they really shifted too? I think that has a 
lot to do with it. I often don't eat lunch until 2PM or so. I usually don't 
eat dinner until at least 10PM. It's hard to go to sleep at 1 or 2 if I ate 
dinner at 11:30. It's a vicious cycle.  Go to bed late, wake up late, so 
get to work late, so you have to leave work late, when means you decompress 
late, and cook late, and eat late, then go to bed late again. You can't 
force yourself to sleep. I can try to force myself to wake up, but 
productivity would go way down. I would be tired during working hours, but 
somehow wake up after dinner, and not be able to sleep until late again.
comments.author: cbernier3

comments.author: Donnie

comments.text:
+Donnie  You are normal. Most people aren't susceptible to alcoholism. It 
takes a ton of alcohol abuse for your body to start developing physical 
dependencies. Alcohol and weed isn't like opiates or nicotine. No, I don't 
think your friends became dependent after just 10 cigarettes. The problem 
with cigarette smokers is they tend to want to smoke them all day long. The 
brain gets used to that and compensates. Meaning, they need the cigarettes 
just to feel normal, and then need more if they want to chase the buzz. 
Occasional tobacco use doesn't cause this. You have it once in a while, 
probably only at night. You brain never learns to compensate and you feel 
normal without it. Caffeine is the same. You need to drink a significant 
amount every day to get addicted. I have a small addiction to caffeine. 
This only happened once I started having caffeine every day. I could quit 
the caffeine easy enough. There would be one day that was bad headache and 
irritable. After a week or so things would be normal again. But without 
caffeine, my terrible sleep habits would catch up with me. I am a night owl 
with an irregular biological clock. I feel that my clock lasts longer than 
24 hours, and that I am jetlagged almost every day. When I quit caffeine it 
doesn't fix these problems. There are people addicted to caffeine way worse 
than me. All I need is a couple Pepsi Max per day. Really only need one, 
but prefer two. That's only like one cup of coffee per day. Addiction goes 
with dependence and withdrawal. You never had dependence or withdrawal, so 
you never got addicted. The problem is when people use drugs to try to 
solve problems. Then they to quit, go through some withdrawal from mild to 
horrible, and their problems come back. If they don't find a real solution 
to their problems, they go back to the drug that helped them. The problem 
is that drugs eventually just cause more problems, and they stop actually 
helping you with your problems. The only permanent solution to my sleeping 
problem is massive lifestyle adjustments. That would require a different 
career, one in which I could set my own hours and work mostly at night. 
Would also have to find friends and a wife that is compatible with this 
lifestyle. This is an unacceptable solution for me, although it works fine 
for some people. I'd rather have to drink caffeine then give up my dream 
career and the hope for a normal life.
comments.author: cbernier3

comments.text:
+Doughli 112 I was more like curious rather than worrying. Why would I be 
worried? I was curious if it's normal to not be an alcoholic after I used 
to drink much more, and more often. And most of my friends who smoke, 
became dependent on tobacco after just ~10 small cigarettes, while I once 
smoked 2 loaded pipes within a week, without a filter, with pure tobacco, 
and didn't get any long-lasting effects.
I just don't experience what others do with substances. I can't understand 
my wife's feelings when she smells a freshly opened pack of coffee (she 
describes it almost like an orgasm). I can't understand how can anyone eat 
more than enough, why would anyone be addicted to alcohol, and so on. I 
don't understand any addiction besides thought stimulation, like games, or 
solving problems.
This is just out of curiosity - maybe it's a condition which is documented. 
Not like a disease condition (because I guess I'm fine with how things 
are), but rather something that would let me know, whether it's ME who's 
different, or what I do is what's different.

Anyone knows the answer?﻿

comments.text: Yes thanks! I'm feeling like a noob right now :)

comments.text:
+Tuấn Anh No. I'm an artist and an responsible user of Cannabis. I have to 
know what I'm dealing with, thus I performed thorough research on a 
subject. Having an education grade is not as necessary as you'd think. With 
the Internet you can educate yourself about all kinds of concepts.
comments.author: EugeneParallax

comments.text:
+EugeneParallax That's a lot clearer. May I ask are you major in 
medication/chemistry because your answers are so knowledgeable.
comments.author: Tuấn Anh

comments.text:
+Tuấn Anh Đỗ Always a pleasure.
In general, it relies on what the brain is working on - chemistry. If you 
take two substancse which work in shared domains, the effect will be 
amplified within the boundaries of brain's tolerance. If you take two 
substances which work on the same aspects in opposite ways, they will 
cancel one another. If you take two substances which work in shared domains 
but has counteracting effects on some of them, the effect gets wonky and 
unpredictable.

The key of understanding the conseqences is to know what receptors are 
amplified or inhibited by the given combination of depressants and 
stimulators, since they can stimulate and depress different aspects of 
brain's functions, which sometimes might seem as the same, but iologically 
are different.
comments.author: EugeneParallax

comments.text:

understand all of it but it sure help a lot. I learn something new today.
comments.author: Tuấn Anh

comments.text:
That depends on the areas of the brain said substances make effects on. 
Also most natural drugs can exhibit the properties of both depressants and 
stimulants depending on the particular case.

An example from my experience is Cannabis and Tobacco. Cannabis has two 
predominant active substances, CannaBiDiol and TetraHydraCannabinol. CBD is 
a substance, which mostly enchance your body functions - increase blood 
vessel pressure and enchances metabolism, causing buffed-up perception and 
functions of endocrine system, while also causing a spontant feel of 
hunger, due to the overtaxed hydrocarbon usage by the aforementioned 
processes. THC on the other hand is a purely psychoactive substance, which 
affects the imagination and creativity, bringing the feel of excitement and 
euphoria, suggestivity to ideas and overall pumped up neural function, 
while in turn can cause very selective long-term memory function and 
anxiety/paranoia if affected person has not prepared the friendly 
environment.

Nicotine is in many terms carries the opposite effect of the Cannabis. It 
stimulates focus, caution and psychical restraint. It reduces blood 
pressure, inhibits emotions, stress signals, and makes you overall more 
timid. Muscle functions are also depressed and it's much harder to make 
physical work or excercises after a cigarette. It inhibits the metabolism, 
easing pain and reducing feeling of hunger, but also makes you feeling your 
body colder and constrained. Due to the almost polar difference of these 
effects to the ones CBD and THC manifests, smoking a cigarette soon after a 
joint can neutralize the effect of the latter almost entirely, and 
repetative cases of such misuse can stress the circulatory system due to 
constant change of blood pressure and cause headaches, feel of uneasiness 
and depression.

top_comment.text:
Did you do one about antidepressant and antipsychotic medications? Do it, 
do it, do it! Many people are being medicated by docs and believe their 
symptoms and disorders are solely due to a "brain chemistry imbalance". 
That is a lie, and is being written about by Harvard professors in depth--- 
using the meds is about the same as using any other drug like cocaine or 
alcohol... the brain adapts and then the person thinks the medication 
"isn't working anymore" and they need a stronger dose, or they MUST have 
the medication simply to get by, or they'll go crazy. That's the real 
problem.... people thinking they NEED extra substances like this because 
they are powerless to take action and manage themselves, that is ADDICTION. 
Tell a doctor you feel anxious or depressed, and they'll offer the meds 
instead of offering you information about nutrition, exercise, sleep, 
allergies, or psychotherapy. In reality medication should be given in short 
term periods... all medication has long term side effects, and for even a 
low dose of Paxil the patient does develop permanent chemical and 
neurological damage resulting in partial paralysis, memory problems, 
chronic pain/numbness, and speech problems. Long term POSITIVE effects on 
the brain can be achieved through diet, exercise, changing sleep patterns, 
changing lifestyles, cognitive therapy, meditation, and psychotherapy. One 
thing people who love their meds can't argue with is that their medication 
will not give them lasting physical benefits. By all means, I have BPD and 
Asperger's and would have been happy to take Celexa for a transition from 
school to university, I do think these medications have a place in the 
world.... just not taken in any dosage for a length of decades. And anybody 
reading this stuff should not immediately go off their meds, because the 
withdrawal can be dangerous and the real damage of the drug (it actually 
masks itself) will be noticeable. Such withdrawal does lead people to 
believe "Look how bad I am without it, I need to be on it forever." No. You 
are not powerless, you really can change your life yourself.﻿

comments.text:
+epsereth Dude, LSD is the LEAST dangerous illicit substance that exists, 
only introduced stress can really mess with that. Even hospitals only deal 
with bad trips by putting the person in a dark and quiet room to mellow 
out. It takes several hundred doses to cause anywhere near a risky 
overdose. So +butterflycaught900 just put on some Dark Side of the Moon and 
stare at a blank wall. You will see the images form slowly and morph into 
one another, mine have mostly come as dots and lines that my brain then 
interprets into images. It take around 45 minutes to kick in, and if you 
can I would recommend 2 tabs to get something really good. The first thing 
you'll notice is a lag/drag effect on moving objects, especially those 
closest to you e.g. your hand. It's pretty neat and mesmerizing. That same 
type of rippling also happens to sounds sometimes. If you happen to have 
access to the Hendrix poster with the paint splats in the background it is 
most excellent to look at when in the zone. When I did it it was flying 
just off the wall like a magic carpet. The total effect lasts about twelve 
hours, so you must be prepared for that duration, it includes both the 
upswing and the downswing. All in all you might feel a little bummed for a 
few days after, but that is just from the sheer jubilation that the LSD 
causes while you do it.WARNING: THERE ARE VERY LOUD CLOCKS THAT BEGIN 
RINGING FOR A WHILE DURING DARK SIDE, DON'T FREAK OUT.
comments.author: Timothy “The Messiah” Trudel

comments.text:
+Terrell Edwards No, what was covered barely scratch the surface of those 
two topics. I can not think of one study he has refer to in this series yet.

What gets taught in Psychology, (even at a basic level), just for memory is:
Lofus' and Plamer's study on eye witness testimony (1974), Atkinson's and 
Shiffrin's work on long term and short term memory. (1968), Bartlett work 
on constructive models of memory (1932), Miller (1955), Bousfield (1953), 
Tulving and Pelstone (1966), Ebbinghaus (1885), Baddeley (1995) Craik and 
Lockhart (1972), and a few other more.

comments.text:
Not entirely sure this is what it means, but I'll try and describe the 
feeling of when I was hypnotized (and, to a lesser extent, when I meditate 
or have a panic attack). Imagine you're aware of what's going on around 
you, but you just have very little control over your body. In the case of 
hypnosis, you may want to move, but you're just...too relaxed, so no matter 
what, you can't seem to move. It's as though your brain and your body have 
disconnected--what you want to do is not what you actually do. In addition, 
though you're aware of most things around you, your sense of time is 
altered--what may feel like minutes can actually last hours. In normal 
meditation, it's similar, though it's much easier to be "snapped out of it".

The exact opposite type of dissociation occurs in a panic attack. Rather 
than being too relaxed to do anything, you're instead too wound up to do 
what you want. You often realize you're having an attack, but that doesn't 
stop you from saying or doing things you don't want to anyway. You may 
scream, or punch things, or cry; you may start telling yourself or anyone 
around that you're contemplating suicide, even if you're not actually. You 
may run from something that you truly want to be part of. All sorts of 
things. And only once you've calmed down do you regain control.

So in essence, losing your sense of self is just the feeling you get when 
what you WANT to do isn't what you ACTUALLY do, even as you're realizing 
it's happening in the moment. When you can't seem to control your actions. 
The most accurate description I can think of is the way I used to describe 
my panic attacks to my ex: it's like you have multiple personalities, 
except they all claim to be you and you remember everything they do. Which 
is actually a more accurate description than it seems at first, because 
from what I understand, multiple personality disorder is actually a severe 
form of dissociation (hence the modern name for it, dissociative identity 
disorder).
comments.author: IceMetalPunk

comments.text:
I think it varies depending on the case. In my personal experience with 
dissociation, it could be like sleeping. I was vaguely aware that time had 
passed, but with almost no memory of what was happening. In the few flashes 
that I do remember, I had no identity, personality, life memories, or 
higher cognitive functions. From the outside, what those around me had 
witnessed, I was upright, able to respond to commands, answer questions 
(usually incorrectly), and sat babbling incoherently for a while. Totally 
awake, but totally not 'present' or aware of myself or able to process the 
situation.

That's extreme though. I imagine meditation or 'zoning out' are more common 
forms where your mind is somewhere else, but not thinking of anything 
specific. I dunno.

takes zero offense because she calls her female friends dude, and even her 
mother. 

But apparently it used to mean a clean-shaven well-dressed city-slicker who 
can't handle rural life competently. 

As in "Yankee *dood*le came to town, riding on a pony, stuck a feather in 
his hat and called it macaroni."

Macaroni used to be considered an exotic dish in America, and the song 
talks about a "dandy" coming into a rural town dressed in fashionable 
European clones nobody in the town has seen before. He comically 
mistranslates the feather in his hat as "macaroni."

Doodle got shortened to dood, and then a misspelling "dude" took precedence.

Sometimes people on the internet say "dood" or "d00d" to be ironic. But the 
true irony is that they're closer to the original spelling.

Language is a storm that never ends, and the second longest-running storm

captions.text: Lemme get your mind right about hypnosis.

First of all, it’s a real thing -- but it’s
probably not what you think it is.

All kinds of hypnosis-esque practices have
been around for centuries, but the Western

version of it -- including the kind that you
probably associate with people being made

to cluck like chickens on stage -- cropped
up around the 18th century, that’s when

German physician Franz Mesmer started treating
all manner of medical problems by putting

patients into a trance-like state, during
which he claimed to align their “internal

magnetic forces,” which he called “animal
magnetism.”

And many of these mesmerized patients did
feel better, but not because of any magnetism

or whatever. Mesmer was inadvertently using
the healing power of suggestion.

In addition to his magnetic quackery, other
physicians didn’t appreciate Mesmer’s

kitschy penchant for wearing capes and playing
ethereal music on a glass harmonica, and eventually
he was discredited.

So were his patients just gullible idiots,
or was there something else going on?

Well, we’ve previously defined consciousness
as our awareness of ourselves and our environment,

and consciousness is at work pretty much whenever
we’re awake, but also while we’re asleep
and dreaming.

So hypnosis is a good example of an altered
state of consciousness -- when you’re fully

conscious in the clinical sense, but also
not in what you’d consider a normal waking

state. As a person who considers himself only
the product of one of several states of consciousness,

this one that I am currently in right now,
it’s worth pointing out how TREMENDOUSLY

WEIRD THIS IS! My brain has these other gears
that it occasionally drops into during which,

in a sense, I become not me any more.
Altered states can also include things like

hallucinations, and the effects of psychoactive
drugs. But these states aren’t as uncommon

as you might think. In fact, you’ve probably
experienced an altered state yourself… even

if you’ve never taken an illicit drug or
been to a cheesy dinner-theater where the

main act wore a glittering turban.
[INTRO]

So, personal opinions of Mesmer aside, here
are some facts and fallacies worth knowing
about hypnosis.

First off, let’s define hypnosis simply
as a calm, trance-like state during which

you tend to have heightened concentration
and focus, and in which you’re typically

more open to suggestion.
The phenomenon has been observed in lots of

empirically rigorous studies, and it’s been
used effectively in treatments for stress
and anxiety, weight loss, and chronic pain.

BUT! It’s important to understand that even
though you’re more open to suggestion when

hypnotized, you do NOT lose control over your
behavior.

So, contrary to what you might see in The
Manchurian Candidate or Zoolander, hypnosis

can’t make you act totally against your
will and, say, jump off a building, rob a
donut shop, or commit a murder most foul.

Nor is hypnosis a reliable way to enhance
the recall of deeply buried memories. We don’t

file away every single one of our experiences.
We only permanently store some of them, and

even they tend to mutate over time. We’ll
be talking all about memory in an upcoming

lesson.
Finally, only about 20 percent of us are thought

to be highly hypnotizable. Those are the folks
whom a hypnotist could get to smile at the

smell of sour milk just by suggesting it was
rosewater.

And even though we know hypnosis can increase
your suggestibility, there’s still some

disagreement about what exactly constitutes
a hypnotic state, or how it’s achieved.

Remember, just because we observe a phenomenon
doesn’t mean that we have a clue about its

mechanisms of action, or whether it works
the way we think it works.

One popular theory looks at hypnosis as phenomenon
of social influence. This camp suggests that,

like actors caught up in an intense role,
hypnotized subjects may begin to feel and

act like “good hypnotic subjects” if they
just trust their hypnotist to sort of act

like a director and focus their attention.
Other researchers suggest that it has more

to do with a special dual-processing state
of split-consciousness called dissociation.

Dissociation is a sort of detachment from
your surroundings, which can range from mild

spacing out all the way up to a total loss
of your sense of yourself. It’s something

we all do to some degree or another, and we’re
often quite aware that we’re doing it. It’s

not hard to think of instances where dissociation
might even help us, like when we’re faced

with a dangerous situation that requires quick,
reflexive action and not a ton of focus on

our own thoughts and feelings.
In this way, hypnosis may ease pain, not by

magically blocking pain receptors, but by
helping us selectively not attend to that

pain. Clinicians can do this by basically
guiding the patient into a very relaxed, but

voluntary state, sort of spaced-out, and then
further guiding them through a series of positive

thoughts and suggestions.
So, in legitimate clinical hypnosis, people

aren’t being made to dissociate. Instead,
think of them as being asked to dissociate

- and some people are better at this than
others, which is essentially what being “highly

hypnotizable” means.
So, clearly there’s a lot going on in our

two-track brains at any given time, and hypnosis
-- as researchers understand it -- seems to

help us tap into some of that adaptive dissociative
capacity that we all seem to have.

But say you’re not so into the idea of someone
feeding you suggestions.

Probably the most classic way to voluntarily
enter an altered state of consciousness is
by using drugs.

Most of us have used some kind of legal drug…
your morning coffee, a beer at lunch, some

Tylenol PM to put you the bed… and lots
and lots of folks responsibly use prescription
and nonprescription drugs.

But of course, some people develop problems.
The more you use a substance, legal or illegal,

the less you feel its effects as your tolerance
grows. And soon enough, a two-beer buzz turns

into a four-beer buzz or a case-of-beer buzz.
That’s your brain chemistry adapting to

offset the drug effect in a process called
neuroadaptation.

Keep on that road and soon you’ll risk a
physical and/or psychological addiction to

the substance you choose, or the substance
that chose you. And that’s not even to mention

serious physiological and neurological damage,
as happens with severe and long-term alcohol

abuse.
We’ll be delving more deeply into the science

of addiction in an upcoming episode, but for
now, let’s take a look at some of these

drug families and how they jack you up, knock
you out, make you do dumb things, see imaginary

stuff, and generally alter your consciousness.
Psychoactive drugs are chemical substances

that alter your mood and perception. They’re
the ones that go right to your brain’s synapses,

mimicking the functions of neurotransmitters.
They also work by tapping into the psychological

component - in other words, the user’s expectations
about what substance use might mean. Like

if you really believe that drinking tequila
makes you more aggressive, and I give you

a virgin margarita, your mere expectation
of getting all surly and aggro may actually

lead you to punch someone in the neck. That’s
also called the placebo effect.

Whether smoked, snorted, ingested, or injected,
we’ll put all of them into three general

categories: depressants, stimulants, and hallucinogens.
Depressants, like alcohol, tranquilizers,

and opiates, do exactly what you’d expect--they
bring the mellow, slow body functions, and

suppress neural activity.
Historically, the world’s favorite depressant

is alcohol. Beat writer William S. Burroughs
even called it “our national drug.” A

little bit of hooch may get the party started,
but not because it’s stimulating anyone.

Rather, it’s acting as a disinhibitor, impairing
your brain’s judgement areas, while reducing
your self-awareness and self-control.

And then because alcohol disrupts memory formations
you may wake up wondering where one of your

eyebrows went.
Similar to booze, tranquilizers, or barbiturates,

depress nervous system activity and may be
prescribed to ease anxiety or insomnia, though

high doses can negatively affect memory and
judgement. And really high doses, or bad interactions

with other substances like alcohol, can kill
you.

Opiates, like poppy-flower superstar opium
and its derivatives morphine and heroin, work

in a similar way, depressing neural activity
and enveloping the brain in a fog of no-pain

bliss. The thing is, if a brain keeps getting
flooded with outside opiates, it will eventually

stop brewing its own natural pain killing
neurotransmitters, endorphins. The resulting

withdrawal is particularly nasty.
Stimulants, obviously, excite rather than

suppress neural activity, and speed up body
functions, bringing up your energy, self-confidence,

and changing your mood. On the legal end of
the spectrum here, we’ve got caffeine, nicotine,

and prescription amphetamines, building up
to the more serious illegal stuff like street

amphetamines, meth, Ecstasy, and cocaine.
And you know who loved his coke? Freud. He

loved i—t so much—it cheered him up when
we was feeling down, opened up his mind, and

turned him into chatty Kathy. He even wrote
his first big publication, “Über Coca”

in 1884 about it. During his famous coke years
in his late 20s and 30s, he believed that

the drug was a viable cure for morphine addiction.
Which… not so much.

Luckily he gave his nose a rest and finally
dropped the habit by his 40s to focus full-time

on his cigar addiction. Which is the thing
that ultimately killed him.

Cocaine hits the bloodstream in a flash of
energetic euphoria that quickly taxes the

brain’s supply of dopamine, serotonin, and
norepinephrine. Methamphetamine also triggers

the release of dopamine. You’ll remember
from our lesson on neurotransmitters how these

chemical messengers affect our moods, emotions,
attention, and alertness. So when those neurotransmitters

are excessively activated, they can become
temporarily depleted, which is what causes

that agitated, depressive crash that users
often feel.

If you drink coffee every morning, and then
you skip a day, you’ll likely be tired and

cranky with a pounding headache. Now multiply
that awful feeling by like thousands and you’ll

see why people with coke and meth addictions
might keep chasing that high while their bodies

and lives fall apart around them.
In addition to depressants and stimulants,

we’ve got hallucinogens, which come in a
variety of plant and fungal forms, as well

as synthetic forms like LSD or lysergic acid
diethylamide. Also called psychedelics, these

drugs distort perceptions and evoke sensory
images in the absence of actual sensory input.

Which means you could end up seeing, hearing,
smelling, or feeling things that are not real.

This could be quite nice, if you’re like,
petting baby dolphins or something, but it

could also be panic-inducing and generally
messed up, if you think you’ve got a bunch

of centipedes crawling under your skin.
The thing is, there are lots of ways to involuntarily

hallucinate without the use of drugs. Seizures,
brain injuries, diseases, sensory deprivation,

fever, stress, or even extreme grief or depression
can all cause neurological disturbances that

spur hallucinations of one kind or another.
Many healthy people have reported experiencing

vivid auditory hallucinations when in emergencies,
like, you broke your knee skiing and you wanted

to just fall asleep forever in that blanket
of soft snow, but a strong, seemingly audible

voice ordered you to KEEP MOVING.
And bizarrely, it isn’t uncommon for people

who lose the use of one sense—like vision
or smell--to perceive sights and odors they

are no longer capable of sensing as their
brains pull from old memories to produce hallucinations

as a way to compensate for that loss.
All this just goes to show that whether you’re

a psychologist, neuroscientist, or philosopher,
our various states of consciousness provide

a rich, complex world of inquiry to contemplate,
showing yet again, just what a messy and marvelous

thing the human mind is.
If your consciousness wasn’t too altered

today, you learned what hypnosis is and what
it can and can’t do; how psychoactive depressant,

stimulant, and hallucinogenic drugs work on
the brain; and how non-drug induced hallucinations
can happen to anyone.
